name: Exploring Buddhist Emptiness in Substance Addiction Recovery
description: The study aims to investigate how the Buddhist concept of emptiness relates to experiences of substance addiction recovery for people with long-term sobriety. The research will ask the question: "What is the significance of the Buddhist concept of emptiness to individuals in long-term recovery from substance addiction?" The aim is to capture the relationship between Buddhist emptiness and substance addiction recovery.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Exploring the perceptions of teacher librarians, classroom teachers, and principals regarding the nature, challenges, and opportunities for successful collaboration in  Australian primary schools

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: When Teacher Librarians (TLs) successfully collaborate with Classroom Teachers (CTs), the TLs’ knowledge and expertise are fully utilised, leading to improved student achievement (Lance et al., 2010; Lance & Kachel, 2018). However, in some schools, TLs are underused, and there is limited collaboration between teacher librarians and classroom teachers (Cooper & Bray, 2011; Wersebe, 2018). This research seeks to identify the challenges and opportunities of collaboration as perceived by TLs, CTs, and principals in Australian primary schools. This research undertakes three studies. Study 1 is a systematic scoping review of existing literature to understand the role of TLs in Australian primary schools. The scoping review will inform the design of a new model that demonstrates collaborative practices among TLs, CTs, and principals as they teach students to be digitally and information literate in the modern world. In Study 2, data will be collected through an online survey, where participants will be asked to define collaboration and the role of the TL, as well as to reflect on their current experiences and explain what TL-CT collaboration looks like in practice. Study 3 will involve qualitative, semi-structured interviews with TLs, CTs, and principals to gain deeper insights into collaboration, including the perceived challenges that hinder progress and the ideal conditions that support successful collaboration. This study aims to enhance educators’ understanding of what constitutes successful collaboration by providing solutions and future recommendations for TLs, CTs, and principals to strengthen partnerships within schools, along with guidance on their roles in TL-CT collaboration. This proposed PhD by publication aims to produce at least three papers, each derived from the three outlined studies, in an ongoing manner.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Validating and evaluating a multi-joint and isolated calf muscle testing battery

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: The research question associated with this project is “Can reliability and validity be established for testing protocols of the calf muscle that aim to closely replicate the functional demands placed on the calf muscle complex during running and field-based sports? The aims of this project are: 1. To develop a testing battery that assesses MVIC force outputs of the calf in both a vertical and horizontal plane, in a multi-joint position that replicates running demands. a. To assess ground reaction forces in the horizontal and vertical planes during a common calf rehabilitative exercise. 2. To establish the reliability of an isometric and dynamic assessment of calf muscle function. 3. To establish the validity of an isometric and dynamic assessment of calf muscle function. The insights from the MVIC testing battery and rehabilitative exercise performance have the potential to detect athletes at risk of CMSI and to improve rehabilitative practices following CMSI.

name: Is CT brain necessary in elderly patients on anticoagulant/antiplatelet therapy after minor head trauma with no other indications for intracranial haemorrhage?

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description:
The aim of this study is to estimate the incidence of ICH and neurosurgical intervention for patients ≥75 years taking anticoagulant/antiplatelet agents who have had a suspected minor head injury but did not have any other indications for needing a scan on presentation. 

It is hypothesised that the incidence of ICH in elderly patients on anti-coagulant/antiplatelet therapy with no other indicators of head trauma (suspected open or depressed skull fracture; suspected base of skull fracture; vomiting ≥2 episodes; high risk mechanism, amnesia before impact >30 minutes; altered mental state or GCS; loss of consciousness; or alternative concern documented by clinician) will be similar to the emergency department incidence of ICH, which previous studies have estimated at 5%. Furthermore, from those with an ICH on brain CT scan, it is hypothesised that the vast majority will not have a neurosurgical/other intervention that varies from the conservative management for ICH.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Hyperemesis Gravidarum and the Emergency Department: An evaluation of hospital-based treatment for nausea and vomiting in pregnancy and hyperemesis gravidarum.

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: The purpose of this project is to evaluate the management of women who present to an emergency department (ED) with nausea and vomiting in pregnancy (NVP) and/or hyperemesis gravidarum (HG) to develop recommendations for cost effective management and improved experience as both in- and out-patients. This project aims to quantify NVP and HG ED presentations, and determine the admission and management criteria for NVP and HG within the emergency setting. This will be achieved through a representative retrospective analysis of the Westmead Hospital ED database over a ten year period (2014-2024).

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Nurse burn-out in the emergency department: What are the leading factors?

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description:
Emergency departments (EDs) are crucial to the Australian health care system and the demand on them is increasing with nine million presentations to Australian public hospital ED’s in 2023-24. In addition, the wait times to see an ED physician or General Practitioner are increasing and this leads to extra pressure placed on emergency nurses, along with frustrated patients, which may lead to increased violence and aggression in the ED. 
Burn-out is becoming a worrying concern amongst ED nurses. The occupational stressors such as excessive workload, violence and aggression, and staff shortages are placing increased pressure on nurses, which is affecting nurses’ well-being and attrition. The increasing number of ED nurses leaving their job, and the nursing profession is concerning, therefore it is important to understand the stressors and employ strategies to protect these nurses from burn-out, which will may lead to improved retention and improved patient outcomes.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Maternity Acupressure Training for Healthcare Providers in India. Assessment Of Program Delivery at Fernandez Foundation and Associated Hospitals, Hyderabad India
description:
The use of acupressure and massage during childbirth has been shown to be effectiveness for supporting normal labour, reducing unnecessary medical interventions, and increasing satisfaction for women during birth. For hospitals, these approaches are low-cost and straight-forward to implement. Importantly acupressure and massage provide natural pain management and improve the experience of childbirth, which many women describe as traumatic due to medical interventions. 
To understand the effectiveness of the training program and to understand how these modalities are used maternity services, this study will use on online survey tool, containing 10-point scales to ask healthcare providers about any changes in their level of skill and knowledge in using these techniques before and after training, and then 6 months after training. 
We will also ask if they are using the skills 6 months after training, and what might help them to implement the skills more effectively.

name: Lived experience of diverse sexual identity in 1st generation Australians

description: This study will be an exploration into the lived experience of diverse sexual identity in first generation Australians. Through the utilisation of semi-structured interviews, this study aims to foster greater understanding of the experience of sexually diverse migrants and shed light on the unique struggles experienced by this group.

It involves a large scale quantitative online survey.

name: Clinician perspectives on caring for patients undergoing short conscious gynaecological procedures.

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description:
Short, conscious gynaecological procedures are performed regularly at Women and Newborn Health Services (WNHS) as an essential component of caring for women.  This service contributes significantly to “A life course approach to health” as defined by the National Women’s Health Strategy 2020-2030 (2019), by way of preventative health, diagnosis, treatment and management of gynaecological conditions.  Anecdotal evidence from staff at King Edwards Memorial Hospital (KEMH) caring for patients undergoing these procedures, suggests there is a variation amongst patients’ experience of this service. 
Aim
This project aims to understand clinician’s perspectives and describe their experience regarding the provision of care for patients undergoing short, conscious gynaecological procedures to optimise care provision and identify areas for improvement. 
Methodology
Utilising a lens of quality improvement as defined by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC et al., 2023), this project will adopt a qualitative descriptive design to capture the perspectives of health professionals. 
Significance
Understanding the perspective of fellow clinicians on what their colleagues feel is done well and areas for improvement will provide evidence to assist in improving this model of service delivery.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Investigating the impact of acute surgery timing on short-term post-burn outcomes in adult burn patients

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description:
Burns are one of the most common forms of traumatic injuries globally, and are
attributed to longer stays in hospital, particularly in the intensive care unit (ICU), compared to
other injuries. Burn pathophysiology is complex, consisting of multiple phases of disordered
metabolism that contribute to the challenge of burn treatment and management.
While there are studies in the published literature that provide evidence for the benefits
of early excision and grafting of burn wounds, there is still no consensus for the optimal timing
to burn surgery for adult patients, in terms of what is early and how to translate earlier surgery
into practise.
Using data collected in the Western Australian Burn Clinical Data Registry since 2004,
this retrospective cohort study aims to explore this gap in the literature. From a sample
population consisting of patients that underwent surgery for their burn injuries, patients will be
categorised into cohorts (<48 hours, 48 hours to 5 days, and >5 days) derived from the time
between burn diagnosis and burn surgery. The associations between time to surgery and
variables including length of hospital stay (LOS), duration of care, hospital-acquired
complications (HACs) and in-hospital intervention will be statistically analysed for
significance.
The results of this study aim to better inform surgical management of burns in an acute
setting. By potentially providing evidence for improved outcomes, these results will clarify the
optimal timing of burn surgery for better short-term post-operative outcomes.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: ACL Injury Research Project

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: Retrospective analysis of acute anterior cruciate ligament injuries. Predictors of referral for surgical versus conservative management.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: A retrospective analysis of BioBanked samples for the genetic investigations and future treatment of neuromuscular disorders.

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: To investigate the influence of genetic variations in Biobanked amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and Parkinson’s disease (PD) samples to determine their association with disease onset and disease phenotype. To investigate functional and structural changes in patient and healthy derived cells for the purposes of ALS and PD research, with a focus on the genetic variations identified in BioBanked DNA samples. To screen antisense oligonucleotide therapies in a cell model of ALS and PD.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Measuring Patient-Centred Care: Common data sets for acupuncture trials across women’s lifespan
description:
This study is proposing a method for establishing a common outcome sets (COS) for acupuncture trials for women’s health across the lifespan. Using the methods described by the COMET Initiative (https://www.comet-initiative.org/), where common outcome measures are established in various health conditions, following a set process. 
This study aims to present a method for establishing common outcome sets (COS) for acupuncture for women’s health across the lifespan. We will describe a method for consultation and consensus using the process described by the COMET Initiative, where researchers, clinicians and consumers contribute to the creation a set of relevant outcome measures, meaningful to researchers, practitioners, and consumers for trials of interventions, which in this case is acupuncture trials in women’s health.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Evaluation of volunteer biography services in palliative care

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: This is a mixed-method cross-sectional evaluation study of volunteer biography services in two palliative care services, incorporating six stakeholder groups, palliative care patients, their family carers, bereaved carers, referrers, volunteer biographers and volunteer managers, all of whom will be asked to complete a questionnaire and participate in an interview.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Identifying unique immune mechanisms in melanoma patients with brain recurrence or pre-surgical progression on neoadjuvant therapy

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: This research project is designed to uncover the immunological drivers of treatment resistance in melanoma patients, specifically those who recur in the brain or exhibit disease progression before surgery while on neoadjuvant therapy. By identifying unique immune populations and markers of resistance, this project aims to better understand the underlying mechanisms that contribute to immunotherapy resistance and super progression in these patients. The insights gained could lead to the development or targeted therapeutic strategies the circumvent resistance and that can be further tested in mechanistic or pre-clinical models, ultimately improving patient outcomes and survival rates in these particularly challenging cases.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Prediction error in the testing effect; influences on learning and decision-making

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: This project examines whether intentionally introducing uncertainty into a well‐established causal learning paradigm (the allergist task) can enhance the testing effect. By manipulating the feedback to include uncertainty cues, we aim to measure improvements in retrieval practice and assess whether enhanced prediction errors lead to better retention and transfer of learned cause–effect associations. The outcomes may inform new teaching strategies to improve learning in classroom settings.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: The role of stakeholder beliefs on the pedagogical decisions teachers make about play in early childhood

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: The primary purpose of this study is to investigate the beliefs and perspectives about play held by teachers, children and parents from a variety of schools and then consider how those beliefs and perspectives influence pedagogical decisions, and the provisions made for play in Western Australian (WA) Pre-Primary (PP) - Year 1 (Yr1) school settings. The aim of this study will be fourfold. First, to explore the beliefs, perspectives and practices of early childhood (EC) teachers who identify as being play-based in their approach to teaching and learning and consider how these beliefs are reflected in the environment, early childhood curriculum, teaching pedagogies and learning experiences employed in PP-Yr1. Second, to investigate the beliefs and practices of children towards play and play-based teaching and learning. Third, to explore the beliefs and perspectives of parents towards play and play-based teaching and learning. Finally, the research will aim to provide an in-depth account of the actual affordances and hindrances to play and implementing a play-based approach during these critical EC years in WA.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: A Prospective Cohort Study Evaluating the use of Ritual, Spiritual Orientation and Coping
description: Our primary objective is to better understand the range, type and frequency of rituals commonly practiced by patients with an advanced illness and an estimated prognosis of ≤12 months.  Secondarily, this study seeks to better understand what spiritual practices patients would like to have in their lives but currently do not.  Thirdly, we seek correlations between patient/carer coping, quality of life and subjective spirituality and practices of rituals that are personally or culturally meaningful activities.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: The THRIVE study- Transformative Healing Resources In Valuable Environments, identifying intrinsic and extrinsic factors that support Post Traumatic Growth in Nurses

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description:
This mixed-method explanatory sequential research will recruit registered nurses via social media sites to identify intrinsic and extrinsic factors that promote post traumatic growth. The aim is to identify intrinsic and extrinsic factors that support nurses following crisis. 
 A validated instrument the Post Traumatic Growth Inventory, will be used in the quantitative phase to measure Personal Strength, Spiritual Change, New Possibilities, Appreciation of Life and Relation to others. The qualitative phase will comprise focus groups from the sub-disciplines of nurses: academics; clinicians; researchers; and managers and will explore intrinsic and extrinsic factors related to growth. Descriptive statistics will be used to analyse quantitative data and thematic analysis will be used for qualitative data. The team comprises nurses from academia, research, clinical and management. 
Prof Betihavas who is the CI on this project has experience researching post traumatic growth as an investigator within national and international research teams.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: A qualitative case study of paediatric war injuries in Gaza – the healthcare provider perspective.

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: This descriptive qualitative study aims to document the nature and consequences of the problems precipitated by serious limb injuries and amputations in children in Gaza from the perspective of health professionals involved in their care.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Assessing the Role of Churches and Christian Values in Bridging Gender Equality Gaps in the Solomon Islands

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: This research aims to assess whether the Christian church and its values serve as an effective tool for changing attitudes and behaviours related to gender inequality in the Solomon Islands. The study will explore how participants perceive gender inequality within their communities and how these views are shaped by Christian beliefs, by collecting primary qualitative data through interviewing participants from five major church denominations in the Solomon Islands. It will also include interviews with key informants such as church leaders, NGO representatives, and program implementers to understand their roles in addressing gender inequality and their views on the effectiveness of faith-based initiatives in shifting harmful gender norms.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: The Archaeology of Point Possession

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: The project aims to answer questions regarding the meaning of many archaeological sites that are located mostly on exposed granite outcrops near Point Possession (part of the Vancouver Peninsula). Using pedestrian transects, one will identify and record the location of the area’s archaeology, producing maps that will allow the Aboriginal community to monitor and care for the archaeology in the future.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: SToP (See, Treat, Prevent) skin sores and scabies trial: study protocol for a cluster randomised, stepped-wedge trial for skin disease control in remote Western Australia
description: The SToP trial is an (open-cohort) stepped-wedge cluster randomised trial that aims to evaluate a skin health programme comprising three intervention components (1) seeing skin infections; (2) treating skin infections; and (3) preventing skin infections. Four community clusters in the remote Kimberley region of Western Australia participated in the study. The primary outcome is the diagnosis of impetigo in children (5–9 years) observed during school-based surveillance visits.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Connections to people, places and God, 2 years on from an immersive experience in the Holy Land

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: The purpose of this research is to use student data from post-graduate students at the University of Notre Dame, Fremantle campus enrolled in Master courses in Religious Education, from one-on-one semi-structured interviews to assess the on-going effects of a pilgrimage to Israel, after two years of the pilgrimage.  An additional aim is ascertaining the extent that the pilgrimage experience has impacted on the students who are teachers and leaders of Religious Education (RE) in Catholic schools.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Trends in Intracerebral Haemorrhage (ICH) hospitalisations and surgical management in Western Australia from 2000 - 2022: data-linkage study.

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: Intracerebral haemorrhage (ICH) is the subtype of stroke with the most devastating consequences. Despite advances in the medical and surgical management of ICH, the one-month mortality rate is 35%. Trends in ICH have not been studied before in Western Australia. Therefore this study will use a linked dataset of WA hospitalisation and death records to assess trends in ICH hospitalisations. The study will also look at which surgical procedures are being performed and assess these trends. This project is a subset of an existing project titled 'The Real and Changing Atherothrombotic Disease Burden and Secondary Prevention'.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: The lived experience of young adults’ use of online and offline spaces in gender identity development

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: The aim of this project is to investigate the experiences and preferences of gender diverse young adults during gender identity exploration across online and offline spaces (i.e., settings, locations, social media platforms, etc).

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: The lived experience of providing services in rural areas under the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS)

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: This project will be used to explore the experience of rural-based clinicians and support workers who provide services to people accessing the National Disability Insurance Scheme. Study participants will be accessed through contact details sourced from the publicly available database of NDIS service providers. Recruitment will also be sought through snowball sampling by asking participants if there are other key informants that may be able to provide insight into this phenomena. Participants will be asked to engage in a semi structured interview and provide demographic data. This next phase of the project will explore the experiences and perceptions of rural-based medical practitioners, specifically general practitioners and paediatricians who are involved in supporting people who have a disability, reside in a rural area of Australia and receive funding under the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS). We will conduct semi-structured interviews by phone, video call or face-to-face about their experiences supporting people receiving NDIS funding/ Interviews will be transcribed and thematically analysed.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Mortality of people with lived experience of homelessness in Western Australia based on coronial data

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: The aim of this project is to develop comprehensive mortality profiles and investigate the role of housing status in deaths amongst people with lived experience of homelessness in Western Australia. The project objectives are to (i) develop comprehensive mortality profiles of PEH in WA based on coronial data, including with respect to age, cause of death, and amenability to early intervention or treatment, (ii) investigate the extent to which known medical treatments (e.g., cancer treatments) were being utilised by individuals in our cohort around the time of their deaths, (iii) investigate and characterise the extent to which past and present living situation/housing status is documented in Australian coronial data and (iv) investigate the extent to which the living situation/housing status of PEH in our cohort prior to and at the time of their deaths played a role in those deaths.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Quantifying ischemic preconditioning "dose" using thiol oxidation state of albumin

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: This project aims to investigate the response of a novel blood marker to an ischemic preconditioning protocol that can be used to enhance performance in elite athletes. Ischemic preconditioning involves the use of cycles of blood flow restriction prior to exercise in order to stimulate a protective mechanism in the body which leads to enhanced exercise performance. The outcomes of this investigation will show whether it is possible to detect changes in albumin, which is the most abundant protein in human blood, as a result of the IPC protocol and subsequent exercise.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Strategic leadership and educational change: Exploring the importance of planning and leading for success in schools

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: The project will investigate the role of Strategic Leadership in achieving change within schools. Through using case study methodology, the investigation will use semi-structured interviews, a survey and document analysis to build a conceptual model of Strategic Leadership and how it creates conditions for change.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Spiritual wellbeing: the perceptions of Catholic school principals in Western Australia

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description:
The aim of the research project is to explore the perceptions of Catholic school principals about their spiritual wellbeing. In particular, to explore ways the principals consider their spiritual wellbeing is supported, and how their spiritual wellbeing influences their role and how they lead. 
Given this aim, there are two research questions:
1.	In what ways do Catholic school principals perceive their spiritual wellbeing is supported?
2.	How do Catholic school principals perceive their spiritual wellbeing influences their role and how they lead?

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: On-Country cross-cultural immersion programs for the Western Australian judiciary: A participatory action research project to inform design, delivery and impact
description: This Participatory Action Research (PAR) project seeks to determine what is ‘best practice’ in the design, delivery and evaluation of on-Country cross-cultural education programs for judges in WA, and to what extent these programs are leading to changes in policy and practice. Co-researchers will include people who are (or have been) involved in the on-Country immersions, including judicial representatives, on-Country hosts, facilitators and interpreters. An Aboriginal Reference Group will oversee the cultural aspects of the research. Methods include one-on-one interviews, courtroom observations, and analysis of court documents. The co-researchers in the PAR will use the findings to inform the design, delivery and evaluation of future programs; develop a 'Theory of change for two-way learning'; and create a framework to inform future evaluations of on-Country programs. The project ultimately aims to build towards a more culturally-safe court environment for Aboriginal people in Western Australia’s criminal justice system.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Assessing patient safety culture in operating room nurses in a tertiary hospital: a cross-sectional survey using the Australian Hospital Survey on Patient Safety Culture (A-HSOPS) 2.0

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: Patient safety is a crucial objective for health service organizations and is often used as an indicator of the quality of care provided. A poor patient safety culture can lead to adverse events, increasing patient morbidity, mortality, hospitalizations, and overall healthcare costs. This study is to assess the patient safety culture among OR nurses at Royal Perth Hospital using the A-HSOPS 2.0. This cross-sectional survey tool, developed by the Australian Commission on Safety and Quality in Health Care (ACSQHC), will help identify key areas for improvement in patient safety culture, with the ultimate goal of enhancing patient safety.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Researching the lived experience of First Nations Peoples on prepayment meters

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: Our project will build upon these previous research studies to better understand the lived experience of consumers using prepayment metering across Australia. Across the jurisdictions in which pre-payment operates there are likely to be diverse views and experiences about its impact on energy security, consumer rights and protections, and community wellbeing. This will be based on prevailing temperatures and whether solar has been rolled out in these communities. There are also differences in how prepayment for electricity operates in the Northern Territory, Western Australia, South Australia, and Queensland.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Exploring General Practitioners’ communication preferences from pharmacists in Asthma and COPD management: A qualitative focus group study

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: The aim of the study is to improve interprofessional collaboration between general practitioners (GPs) and community pharmacists (CPs) by exploring GPs’ communication preferences from pharmacists, which will support the development of efficient and timely communication pathways. This will lead to safer and more coordinated care for patients with asthma and COD, especially in relation to medications and supporting treatment adherence according to the previous studies. The objectives are (1) to explore GP’s preferences and expectations regarding communication from pharmacists in terms of asthma and COPD management, (2) to assess challenges and barriers that GPs encounter secondary to the current lack of a systematic communication strategy around GPs and pharmacists, (3) to identify enablers that support interprofessional collaboration from the insights of GPs, and (4) to identify recommendations for GPs-pharmacists communication strategies aligned with the existing GPs’ electronic medical record (eMR)and clinical workflows.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Comparison of stability of Saturne and Pinnacle uncemented acetabular cups

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: Retrospective study analysing patients of The Joint Studio (Hollywood Medical Center) who underwent total hip arthroplasty between 2018-2023. The clinical outcomes and patient satisfaction ratings of two brands of uncemented hip implants will be assessed: the Pinnacle (DePuy) and the Saturne (Amplitude) acetabular cups. This will enable conclusions to be drawn about the stability of each hip implant (likelihood of dislocation).

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Why we came and stayed: understanding a lifetime of occupational experiences of senior rural nurses to impact the future: A Mixed Method Study

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: The aim of this research project is to explore how the experiences of senior rural nurses and the perspectives of the newly graduated nurses can be used to impact the future attraction and retention of rural nurses

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Jumping In: The Impact the Olympics has on Sports and Participation rates in Swimming Clubs and Little Athletics and the Impact this has on Participation Rates in independent schools Across Western Australia.

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: This study aims to explore the impact the Olympic games has on participation rates in sporting clubs and the impact that this four year cycle has on participation rates in schools across Western Australia. The data was collected from, Swimming Western Australia, Athletics West and Independent school in Western Australia. In this study there is a trend analysing the increase of participation rates in sporting clubs after the Olympics every four years from 2015 to  2024. The data is categorised yearly participation rates from Swimming Western Australia (WA), Athletics West. As well as the impact the Olympics has on Independent schools participation in swimming and athletics. These results indicate that there is a four-year cycle impacting sporting clubs’ for both swimming and athletics participation. Likewise there is a  correlation impacting positively on Independent schools. This study also serves as a guide to make recommendations that schools consider adapting programs with the potential to see greater participation co-synced with the four year Olympics cycle.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: An exploration of counsellors’ perspectives of the psychosocial needs of their clients experiencing infertility.

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: This research project will provide a nuanced and contextually rich understanding of counsellors’ perspectives on the psychosocial needs of their clients who are experiencing infertility and the interventions that best support them. By conducting semi-structured interviews and analysing the qualitative data using reflective thematic analysis, this project will offer depth and insights into the complexity of counsellors’ experiences within the infertility space.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Healthcare Interprofessional Education (IPE) online experience
description: Collaborative student activities delivered online around a fictional patient scenario to advance Interprofessional learning (IPE) and cooperation. The IPE was previously delivered f2f but the team created an online environment and now seeks to evaluate the students' use of and collaboration within the range of activities. We also wish to understand if there were a change in the students' confidence levels.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: Impact of NICU admission on term infants’ feeding choices at Fiona Stanley Hospital: Barriers, Facilitators and Outcomes

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: Retrospective cohort study investigating the rate of breastmilk at first feed and discharge in the Neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) for term neonates (>37 weeks gestation). The project investigates hospital data from Fiona Stanley for both mother and infant dyads, where term neonates born were admitted to the NICU.

publisher.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

name: A Cross-Sectional Study of Australian Shamanic Healers: Training Backgrounds, Healing Interventions, and Attitudes Toward Mental Health Professions

editor.name: The University of Notre Dame Australia

description: This study is a cross-sectional survey of Australian shamanic healers. It explores the training Australian shamanic healers have undertaken along with the interventions they use when providing shamanic healings to people for emotional and mental health problems. The study also explores their personal mental health experiences and their attitudes towards traditional mental health providers such as general practitioners and psychologists.

name: Breaking Barriers: Unveiling Obstacles to Teaching Standards 1.4 and 2.4

name: Barriers and Enablers of Nurse-led Skin Cancer Screening in Rural Australia
description: Australia has among the highest incidence of skin cancer in the world; two out of three people in Australia will have some form of skin cancer by age 70. Those living in regional and rural areas have a higher incidence of skin cancer than their metropolitan counterparts, and yet, the reach of skin cancer services to regional, rural, and remote Australia is limited to non-existent. General Practitioners (GPs) are primarily responsible for opportunistic skin cancer detection, often made difficult by constrains on consult times, further exacerbated by the maldistribution of primary care providers in rural areas. One solution may be to better utilise nurses as primary providers of skin checks in collaboration with these GPs. This study will examine the barriers and enablers of nurse-led skin checks in rural Australia. Semi-structured interviews will be used to assess the perceived barriers and enablers to a nurse-led screening model, from the perspective of the practitioners who deliver these services. If successful, this project will highlight how to improve future implementation of a nurse-led screening model, and better position future skin screening methods for uptake in rural communities.

publisher.name: https://ror.org/02stey378

name: Assessing the Preparedness of Australian Nurses for Primary Care: An Evaluation of Primary Care Nursing Skill Sets
description: This project focuses on primary care nurses, whose role is crucial in ensuring access to healthcare, improving patient outcomes, reducing healthcare costs, supporting public health initiatives, and achieving health policy goals. Specifically, it aims to evaluate the preparedness of the Australian nursing workforce to address these opportunities. It aims to test the hypothesis that " the existing nursing education programs in Australia are not sufficient to equip graduates for effective job readiness in the primary care environment." This will be done by an analysis of  training nursing curricula and then a comparison made  between skills taught and those required to work in General Practice  and Primary Care nursing.

publisher.name: https://ror.org/02stey378
